comments.commentBody: And then, of course, there was that time when Ed Wood Jr.,  directing Plan 9 From Outer Space, dealt with the loss of his star, Bela Lugosi, by replacing him with his cape-wearing chiropractor at midpoint in the production schedule.
Exactly.
I agree.  It seems ridiculous until it's not so ridiculous.  These detailed assessments also provide for a real reckoning with strengths and weaknesses.

I think that for a child who is doing well in school this seems a bit excessive, however, for a child who has an unknown learning disability, this 8 pager could be the ticket to a screening. It might seem silly but this sounds brilliant to me. Able to write with crayons, stays on task, dictates thoughts. All skills needed for success later in school. So many kids skate through the early years until they hit a wall and by then precious time has been lost. Something this complete will allow teachers to tease out problems before they have a chance to cause real harm.

I say this is a big time positive.

Sorry, though that your kid did not turn out perfect. My son would have scored way below yours do to extreme learning differences.

In the interest of fairness and full disclosure,  the phrase, "They is no tax revenue..," was the result of a lack of proofreading, and not directly caused by conservative-led school closures.  I apologizes for any miscontruance.

Steve Bolger,

Yes. I have talked about multiple changes to the law in this blog.

The claim to these island may have something to do with potential offshore oil or gas. That however is only one aspect of this, and not the most important new element.

The zone around the islands is strategic. The strategy of both sides is access denial. The Chinese do not want to be confined to their near coastal waters, and the West wishes to confine them. The Chinese do not want the West operating freely in their near coastal waters, and the West wishes to do so.

These strategic interests arise now because China's military power is rising now. Before, they could not go outside their near coastal waters, nor keep anyone else out. Now they can, and they want to. The West does not want them too.

So these islands are about submarines, patrol aircraft, and surveillance of Chinese waters. They are about China going beyond the "first island chain."

Oil too. Pride too. Japanese pushing, then blaming China for reacting the same way too. But above all it is strategic. That is why the US is being pulled into supporting Japan even though Japan is likely in the wrong here.

oh God Eric..I love you...one recommend and 25 posts...

That is one definition of our cultural gun sickness....

Lincoln would have been proud of you..

What I especially love are our foreign posters....PS, Magic mike, Long shot Lew from Canada...

Lew...had the post post by far...TOUGH BANANAS...

@QP pontificates,

"In fact, MANY, if not MOST, American liberals would even go so far as to agree that America should never have broken with Britain in 1776. Not that anyone but Steve Bolger would ever openly admit that."

Say what?

Can you please offer a citation supporting that ridiculous statement? How would you know what "MANY, if not MOST" American liberals think? The label "Liberal" covers a multitude of beliefs and attitudes -- but never ever ever have I heard the idea that liberals as a group -- or even any liberal individuals, "agree that America should never have broken with Britain in 1776."

You have sunk to a new low. You're right down there with Eric in your propensity to spout complete falsehoods.

Again, can you cite your source for today's contribution to "les conneries"?

@Justin,

My apology is written on a piece of paper that's kept in a locked box buried deep in Washington, DC along with all the money you turned over to social security and the interest you received.

In other words, don't hold your breath.

Jennifer,

Why do you allow foreigners from Canada, Australia, France, Germany and Switzerland to post to this blog?

Is it any coincidence that these socialists share a total contempt for America, the Constitution and the awesome men who created this great nation?

This is an American issue. They have no stake. They have nothing to contribute except insulting our nation. Let them blog in their own countries.

There is a reason we ousted George III.

@Lew,

The CDC should stick to bacteria and viruses - real medical issues and get out of the LE business with which it has no competence.

@Lew,

Somehow, I doubt that anyone in these stories was an NRA member.

If they were then that would have been headline news.

@Lew

Pity that the politicians and police who ave jurisdiction aren't enforcing the law.

Steve, I don't get your point. Can you clarify?

The prosecutor is the one who leveled the charges against her, not any "gunners".

Paul,
Yea, I'm kinda this weird middle ground. I'm an NRA life member, pro-choice, pro-gay marriage, organic food eating, hunting, combat veteran. I just look at things that, people should be allowed to live their lives without other telling them how to live.

But you are missing my biggest point. When talk about "curing the nation of gun violence" you are not truly caring about the real problem. You can't have gun violence without violence. And if you check countries that have banned guns, they still have just as high, if not higher murder, rape, burglary, and robbery static's. Check Britain and Australian to name a couple. So if you really cared about people not being killed so much, you wouldn't look at a gun, you would look at teaching people to respect each other, not just try and ban every thing that comes along, you just end up with a world of idiot's then.

Banning guns analogy, fun time...

You could ban ketchup, and yes ketchup stains would see a significant reduction, but you will still have the same percentage of stains on people. You don't solve the problem by getting rid of something, you would get it by teaching people to be cautious and respectful, so we don't get stain on us or each other.

Kevin D,

The incident was in Georgia, not South Carolina. I know it might not seem like a big difference up there in Indiana, but it is down here.

I am not sure it is fair to say the law sanctions the killing of an innocent. Just because something isn't criminally prosecuted doesn't mean it is ok, or sanctioned. I do hope that folks will take a good look at the case to make sure it was handled correctly. That having been said, I am not sure what would be accomplished by prosecuting Mr Hendrix. But then, I am skeptical of criminal prosecution, and especially imprisonment as the be all answer we seem to make it.

Humm, even though Australia has DOUBLE the amount of assault victims than the US. And Australia has 150% more rape victims than the US does. Or what about Australia has 43% more total crime victims than the US.

Yes, in the US we can definitely rack up some number with murders from a gun, but Australia is doing very well and assaulting and raping its own.

http://www.nationmaster.com/compare/Australia/United-States/Crime

Steve Bolger,

Occasionally we agree. The woman in the Atlanta school who talked down the gun man earlier this year was smart, brave and a real hero. Should. I find myself in a similar situation, I hope I can muster a fraction of her fortitude. Much more my style as well.

Hmmm. So your sister should have been a mind reader? And you're assuming that because she didn't read your mind when your mother was alive, the way to pay her back is to withhold any communication or  sibling affection? You sound resentful but you don't take any responsibility for your lack of communication.  I have another take: your aloofness helped you to keep your sister away. I think you should take a hard look at yourself before losing your cool with your sister. She may have a completely different viewpoint, one which involves you shutting her out.
Me too! I recommend it to young people whom I mentor at work. They love it.
I remember liking that book a lot.
A will? Get a lawyer now.

Your statement is pretty violent in its intent.

Should we lock you up, too?
Keep VIOLENT people locked up till they are dead.
I'd save execution for public lessons: publicly hang a few banksters, brokers, corrupt politicians and similar gangsters, and see how quickly their followers change their behavior.

I don't think people in maximum security prisons are there for the food. My personal opinion is that the focus is on the wrong side. If first felonies or misdemeanors were put into some sort of community service, it would help some of them find forgiveness and acceptance. I'm talking about restoring buildings or driving meals on wheels (someone else should deliver) or just scrubbing bus stop benches. A priest I know that works in the prison system says that many of his charges are very hard on themselves. We need a more positive response to first offenders.

Killing people is a very permanent punishment. I'd save it for special cases, like bombers and drug lords. What to do with the people we cannot reconnect with society? In Africa they just leave groups of such people in the middle of the desert, more than a day's walk from anywhere, and let them deal with themselves. Just deliver supplies once in a while. A very dark part of my mind finds this tempting.

Mac K, The N.O. Saints are being bowled UBER by your beloved Seahawks on the tube tonight...you betcha!
Speaking of Bowls, with this impressive showing on MNFB, they just may have the inside track on the road to the Super Bowl?

Howie
What five said.

Mean Girls.

The theme flew under my radar too. I knee jerked purred for HUMMED and had Klem for CLEM but the rest went well...I love the chestnut being galloped by Russel Baze, a Cal based rider who his 12,000th race in July. No typo, 12 G's, a staggering number of winners. SADDLE SHOES won't cut it (pun intended) for Mr. Baze's line of work. Boots please...On account of my not being able to spell the name of his character, I'll try to get the link spelled out. Carol Channing joins CLEM here.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z0MGulBlg8s

May God Bless,

Bru

eely, I'm a law-abiding citizen. At times, when they want to maximize the use of the extra lanes, the lower part of the sign lights up: Open to all cars.

Ted, you must be channeling the blatantly opportunistic commentor that lies dormant in every one of us. Go for it! Wordplay is free.

Oh, ok. Een kind of gave it away. We've talked about this guy before; I saw him ride very early in his career.

I just had no idea what he looked like.
You gave it away John, nice selection.
Martin, not sure spurs and a crop go together.  I thinks it's one or the other.  But then I never rode horses, only watched them race at Arlington Park.

Don't know about Baltimore but it's still showing here in NYC.  Try naming another movie in which the lead actor manages to hold the screen despite an almost complete absence of dialogue as well as the complete absence of other cast members. Redford does his job but the director, J.C. Chandor, creates the tension.

In every thing we do, people are crazed by the intent, irrational need to go as fast as possible. Car traffic has become a zoo of drivers wanting to exceed the speed limit as much as possible. Stop signs seem designed to be ignored. There is no surprise to this kind of accident. That makes it no less a tragedy.

On the very same day of this accident another locomotive jumped the tracks in southwestern New Mexico, killing all three aboard the locomotive. The train passed me, already out of control, while I was painting at the roadside. The cause of the accident has not yet been determined. I was lucky not to have been hit by it or the debris flying from the ore cars it was hauling.
Do not jump to conclusions.
